2.1. Introduction¶

Present the assumed geometry, the set of equations and the procedure to follow to perform simulations. Explain how the system is discretized, and how the data are stored (flattened)

2.1.1. Geometry and governing equations¶

The steady state dimension-ful drift-diffusion-Poisson equations read

(1)\[\begin{split}\vec{\nabla}\cdot \vec{J}_n &= -e(G-R)\\ \vec{\nabla}\cdot \vec{J}_p &= e(G-R)\\ \Delta \phi &= \frac{\rho}{\epsilon}\end{split}\]

with the currents

(2)\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\vec{J}_n &= -e\mu_n n \vec{\nabla} \phi + eD_n \vec{\nabla}n\\\vec{J}_p &= -e\mu_p p \vec{\nabla} \phi - eD_p \vec{\nabla}p\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

where \(n, p\) are the electron and hole number densities, and \(\phi\) is the electrostatic potential. \(J_{n(p)}\) is the charge current density of electrons (holes). Here \(e\) is positive (the electron charge is \(-e\)). \(\rho\) is the local charge and \(\epsilon\) is the dielectric constant of the material. \(\mu_{n,p}\) is the electron/hole mobility, and is related the diffusion \(D _{n,p}\) by \(D_{n,p} = k_BT\mu_{n,p}/e\). \(G\) is the generation rate density, \(R\) is the recombination. The natural length scale is the Debye length, given by \(\lambda = \epsilon k_B T /(e^2 N )\), where \(N\) is the concentration relevant to the problem.

We suppose that the recombination is through a Shockley-Read-Hall mechanism. The form for recombination is given as

(3)\[R = \frac{np - n_i^2}{\tau_p(n+n_1) + \tau_n(p+p_1)}\]

where \(n^2_i = N_C N_V e^{-E_g/k_BT}, n_1 = N_C e^{-(E_C - E_T) /k_BT} , p_1 = N_V e^{- (E_T - E_V) /k_BT}\), where \(E_T\) is the energy level of the trap state. The above can be derived on very general grounds (see Ref. [FON81], page 34). \(\tau_{n,(p)}\) is the bulk lifetime for electrons (holes). It is given by

(4)\[\tau_{n,p} = \frac{1}{N_T v^{\rm th}_{n,p} \sigma_{n,p}}\]

where \(N_T\) is the three-dimensional trap density, \(v^{\rm th}_{n,p}\) is the thermal velocity of carriers: \(v^{\rm th}_{n,p} = 3k_BT /m_{n,p}\), and \(\sigma_{n,p}\) is the capture cross-section for (electrons, holes). Other recombination processes include radiative recombination, and Auger recombination. Unlike the defect-mediated recombination described above, these processes are respectively second and third order in charge density. For this reason they become more important at higher densities (such as for heavily doped systems, or systems with high generation rate density of electron-hole pairs). On the other hand, Shockley-Read-Hall recombination is first order in charge density.

2.1.2. Boundary conditions in the \(x\)-direction¶

The boundary conditions for carriers at charge-collecting contacts located at \(x=0\) and x = L are typically parameterized with the surface recombination velocities for electrons and holes at the contacts, denoted respectively by \(S_{c_p}\) and \(S_{c_n}\)

(5)\[\begin{split}\vec{J}_n(0,y,z) \cdot \vec{u}_x &= eS_{c_n} (n(0,y,z) - n_{\rm eq}(0,y,z))\\ \vec{J}_p(0,y,z) \cdot \vec{u}_x &= -eS_{c_p} (p(0,y,z) - p_{\rm eq}(0,y,z))\\ \vec{J}_n(L,y,z) \cdot \vec{u}_x &= -eS_{c_n} (n(L,y,z) - n_{\rm eq}(L,y,z))\\ \vec{J}_p(L,y,z) \cdot \vec{u}_x &= -eS_{c_p} (p(L,y,z) - p_{\rm eq}(L,y,z))\\\end{split}\]

where \(n(p)_{\rm eq}\) is the thermal equilibrium electron (hole) density. In being collected by a contact, a carrier in the valence or conduction band loses its energy and relaxes to the chemical potential of the bulk contact. This is essentially a recombination process. The recombination velocity may be thought of identically as a carrier lifetime in twho dimension (considering Eq. (4) where the trap density is two-dimensional, one obtains units of velocity).

2.1.3. Additional charges¶

Additional charged defect can be added to the system to simulate, for example, grain boundaries in a semiconductor. Grain boundaries separate crystallites of different orientation. They occupy a reduced dimensionality space (e.g. 2D planes embedded in a 3D material), and typically possess a high density of defects (dangling bonds, wrong bonds, cdots). These lead to localized states within the gap, which may lead to charging of the grain boundary, and increased recombination at the grain boundary

(6)\[Q = e\sum_j\frac{\rho_j}{2}(1-2f_j)\]

where \(\rho_j\) is the 2D defect density of the state at energy \(E_j\). The occupancy of the j-th defect level \(f_j\) is given by [SHOXX]

(7)\[f_j = \frac{S_n n_{\rm GB} + S_p \bar p_j}{S_n(n_{\rm GB}+\bar n_j) + S_p(p_{\rm GB}+\bar p_j)}\]

where \(n_{\rm GB}\) (\(p_{\rm GB}\)) is the electron (hole) density at the grain boundary, \(S_n\), \(S_p\) are recombination velocity parameters for electrons and holes respectively. \(\bar n_j\) and \(\bar p_j\) are

(8)\[\begin{split}\bar n_j &= N_C e^{\left(-E_g/2 + E_j\right)/k_BT}\\ \bar p_j &= N_V e^{(-E_g/2 - E_j)/k_BT}\end{split}\]

where \(E_j\) is calculated from the valence band edge, \(N_C\) (\(N_V\)) is the conduction (valence) band effective density of states.

The increased recombination at the grain boundary is included by an additional recombination term \(R_{\rm GB}\) at the grain boundary core

(9)\[R_{\rm GB} = \sum_j \frac{S_nS_p(n_{\rm GB} p_{\rm GB} - n_i^2)} {S_n(n_{\rm GB} + \bar n_j) + S_p(p_{\rm GB} + \bar p_j)}\]

Embedding a two-dimensional density into the three-dimensional model is formally accomplished with the use of a delta function. Numerically, the two-dimensional defect densities of states and the surface recombination velocities are divided by the size of the discretized grid \(dl\) at the position of the plane, and along the direction normal to the plane.

2.1.4. Carrier densities and quasi-Fermi levels¶

Despite their apparent simplicity, Eqs. (1), and the set of boundary conditions of the form of Eq. (5) are numerically challenging to solve. This is due in part to the fact that the carrier densities vary by many orders of magnitude throughout the sample, and because drift and diffusion currents often nearly cancel each other, and the entire solution depends on the small residual current left over. We next discuss a slightly different form of these same equations which is convenient to use for numerical solutions. We introduce the concept of quasi-Fermi level for electrons and holes (denoted by \(E_{F_n}\) and \(E_{F_p}\) respectively). The carrier density is related to these quantities as

(10)\[\begin{split}n(x,y,z) &= N_C e^{\left(E_{F_n}(x,y,z) + q\phi(x,y,z) - b_l\right)/k_BT}\\ p(x,y,z) &= N_V e^{\left(E_{F_p}(x,y,z) - q\phi(x,y,z) - E g +b_l\right)/k_BT}\end{split}\]

where the term \(b_l\) essentially sets (or is set by) the zero of energy for the electrostatic potential (the default value is 0). Quasi-fermi levels are convenient in part because they guarantee that carrier densities are always positive. While carrier densities vary by many orders of magnitude, quasi-Fermi levels require much less variation to describe the system. The signs in Eq. (10) can be confusing; they are such that the carrier density is larger if its quasi-Fermi level is more positive, see Fig. 1.

Fig. 2: Equilibrium energy level diagrams showing the electron quasi-Fermi level in an n-type (p-type) semiconductor on the left (right). We chose \(e\phi = -E_g/2\) to make electron and hole quasi-Fermi levels symmetric.

On an energy diagram, this means that more positive electron quasi-Fermi levels are plotted closer to the conduction band, while positive hole quasi-Fermi levels are plotted closer to the valence band. When plotting both electron and hole quasi-Fermi levels on the same graph (such as on a band diagram), it is therefore necessary to plot, for example, \(E_{F_n}\) and \(-E_{F_p}\) in order to have a consistent sign convention for reading the plot. Signs are confusing additionally because people use different conventions, and sometimes people are careless about them. The signs utilized in these notes and in the code have been checked, and are all self-consistent. Any questions about signs should therefore not be ascribed to typos and the like.

The electron and hole current can be shown to be proportional to the spatial gradient of the quasi-Fermi level

(11)\[\begin{split}\vec{J}_n &= e\mu_n n \vec{\nabla} E_{F_n}\\ \vec{J}_p &= -e\mu_p p \vec{\nabla} E_{F_p}\end{split}\]

These relations for the currents will be used in the discretization of Eq. (1).

References

[FON81]Fonash S. J., Solar cell device physics, Academic Press 1981.
